channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: A program for anonymous railway safety reports has been underutilized
item.description: After the 2023 train crash in East Palestine, Ohio, freight railroads promised to join a federal safety program that lets employees anonymously report mistakes. Only two pilot programs have launched.

item.title: A look at the pomp and pageantry that will define Trump's U.K. summit
item.description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks with Newsweek Chief Royal Correspondent Jack Royston about the pomp and circumstance that will accompany President Trump's meeting with King Charles.

item.title: This book arrived in mailboxes all around Baltimore with no explanation. Until now
item.description: This summer in Baltimore, thousands of copies of the same book showed up in mailboxes and on doorsteps without an explanation. Here's the story behind the mysterious "Great Controversy."

item.title: Vance hosted Charlie Kirk's show Monday in episode that was part tribute, part outrage
item.description: Vice President JD Vance hosted Charlie Kirk's radio program Monday — following last week's murder of the conservative activist.

item.title: Boston church honors enslaved people held by members of the congregation
item.description: A Boston church along the city's Freedom Trail has unveiled a monument to the more than 200 slaves once held by members of the congregation.

item.title: RFK Jr. wants mental health screening out of schools. Here's what experts say
item.description: RFK Jr. thinks kids are stigmatized by mental health screenings. The experts say this is not the case.

item.title: Death row inmate Robert Roberson points to new evidence as execution nears in Texas
item.description: Robert Roberson, who is set to be executed on Oct. 16 for the death of his 2-year-old, maintains that the state used faulty evidence to convict him, pointing to the debunked "shaken baby" diagnosis.

item.title: Tramell Tillman and Britt Lower discuss their characters' evolutions in 'Severance'
item.description: NPR's Scott Detrow speaks to Tramell Tillman and Britt Lower, stars of the Apple TV+ series Severance, about their complex character arcs and show's highly-anticipated second season.

item.title: Israel's once-robust wartime economy starting to show signs of strain
item.description: At almost two years, Israel's conflict with Hamas is its longest ever. But this nonstop fighting is starting to take a toll on the region's most advanced economy.

item.title: Who won — and who spoke out — at the Emmys
item.description: The Studio, The Pitt and Adolescence won big at the Emmy Awards last night. The Late Show With Stephen Colbert took home the prize for best talk series months after CBS announced its cancellation.
